title: Collisions - elastic and inelastic kinetic energy

content.question: In Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, a cart with a spring bumper attached to it moves along a straight, horizontal track with momentum <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi></math> toward an identical cart that is at rest. The bumpers on the carts are facing each other and the carts collide elastically. In Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, a cart with sticky tape attached to it moves along a straight, horizontal track with momentum <math alttext="2 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>p</mi></math>, toward an identical cart that is at rest. The carts collide, stick together, and move together after the collision. Assuming all of the carts have equal masses, which of the following correctly compares the kinetic energies, <math alttext="K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, of the two-cart systems immediately after the collisions in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="K sub 2, equals the fraction K sub 1, end sub, over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>
<math alttext="K sub 2 equals K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="K sub 2 equals 2 K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="K sub 2 equals 4 K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="K sub 2 equals 2 K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
